passages.text:
In 1962, a team of scientists produce a special radio station that had a range of fifteen miles. Even though communication was being accomplished in space at a range of more than a million times this distance, the new radio station caused much excitement among scientist.

The reason: its power supply was a 'battery' made of bacteria. For the first time, practical amounts of electricity were being produced by a form of life and put to use. Bio cell, the fully biological battery, was born.

The battery was a breakthrough because it used natural processes in living cells to produce electrical energy. The scientists discovered that certain bacteria, when fed sugar, released electrons as a by-product of their metabolism. These electrons could be captured and channeled to generate a current.

Although the power output was small, it was enough to operate low-energy devices like the radio transmitter. The implications were enormous: clean, renewable energy from living organisms. Researchers envisioned future applications in medical implants, environmental sensors, and remote monitoring systems — all powered by microbes.

Challenges remained: scaling up the technology, ensuring long-term stability, and increasing efficiency. But the principle was proven: life itself could be harnessed as a power source.
2011 JAMB Use of English, Passage I

The mind is a mysterious thing. It is the seat of thought, emotion, and will. What a man thinks determines what he becomes. Thoughts are the seeds of action. Good thoughts lead to good actions; bad thoughts lead to bad actions. Evil thoughts, if harboured and nurtured, eventually manifest in evil deeds.

It is therefore important to guard the mind. One must be careful about the kind of thoughts one allows to dwell in the mind. The company one keeps, the books one reads, the programmes one watches — all these influence the mind.

A polluted mind produces polluted behaviour. Just as dirty water cannot produce clean ice, so an impure mind cannot produce wholesome conduct. Hence, the need for mental purification.

Purification begins with awareness. One must become conscious of one’s thought patterns and learn to reject harmful or destructive ideas. Meditation, reflection, and positive affirmations can help in this process. Over time, the mind becomes a fertile ground for virtue and wisdom.
2011 JAMB Use of English, Passage II

Though assumption is the lowest level of knowledge; it is still a form of knowledge, and knowledge is key. Assumptions are the foundation upon which interpretation and conclusion are built.

Everything in life operate under certain assumptions. We make management decisions based on the assumptions we hold about how management ought to function and how people ought to be governed.

For some of us, we consciously imbibe assumptions and principles about life and consciously decide based on them; for others, it is unconsciously but potent all the same. Our assumptions will either drown us or help us soar through life.

We have always seen life as an immense mansion with many rooms. Some rooms lead to wealth, others to the opposite. Ultimately, we decide where we end up; and life, thus far, has proved that not everyone of us decides well, we all behave differently where we have different levels of understanding, and behave the way where our understanding is the same.

We eat because we all understand the consequences of not eating. We all wear clothes because each of us comprehends lunacy. The list goes on and on. It is inevitable that some of us will make choices that get and keep us on the lower rung of the ladder by reason of exposure, training or some others variables.

Life is about role playing. We choose our roles wisely or foolishly, consciously or unconsciously. Some of us get wiser to new levels of self-awareness enough to redefine our roles, others make no effort to build further capacity and therefore remain where they are. It is based on those realities that we draw the conclusion that not everyone will be wealthy in life. We lead, inspire and motivate people to strive and succeed.

It is also important that we paint the full and true picture of life so that we can discourage vain pursuits. Balance must be enthroned as a critical component of truth, and people know, for instance, that 'the top' is not a place that all must ascend.

Our greatest consolation lies in our deep conviction that true prosperity is in fulfilment through hard work than in intangible acquisition. There are set roles that some of us have been wired up to play in life but which we are not content enough to play because society esteems such roles to be inferior.
2011 JAMB Use of English, Passage III

Believe it or not, change is to human existence what the blood is to the human body. We live in an era of amazing ......16...... [A. well-define, B. fast-paced, C. favourable, D. social] change spawned by advancing technology and industrialization.

However, man's......17...... [A. Knowledge of, B. attitude to, C. commitment to, D. opinion of] promoting and defending change in a deliberate effort to establish ......18...... [A. customs, B. companies, C. trade-zone, D. variations] that stimulate advancement for man's concern is proving unfavourable to the climate with threatening ......19...... [A. repercussions B. clouds C. pressure D. implication]

Human-induced climate change has awakened widespread concern across the globe. As a matter of fact, climate change is now......20...... [A. an acceptable B. a foremost C. the only D. the last] globe issue. It is a major test of Africa's......21...... [A. popularity B. energy C. ingenuity D. incapability]!

The forth Assessment Report (AR4) of the intergovernmental panel of climate change (IPCC) confirm that human action are changing the earth's climate and creating major disturbance in human......22......[A. geography B. society C. systems D. life] and ecosystems. The IPCC reports that world has warmed by an average of 0.760c since pre-Industrial times.

The rising global ......23...... [A. command B. demand C. warning D. supply] for energy and the adverse changes on each were commensurate with the level of greenhouse ......24...... [A. structure B. paints C. emulsion D. emissions] it spews out, perhaps Africa would have been spared and would probably be just an amused spectator. But as it, this is not the case.

Here again, we see well-meaning global citizen appealing for the rest of the world to take responsibility for the problem of Africa, a strategy that cannot, thus far, be termed ......25...... [A. notable B. liable C. credible D. flexible].
2011 JAMB Use of English, Passage IV

instructions.text: In each of questions 26 to 35, select the option that best explains the information conveyed in the sentence.
In each of questions 36 to 50, choose the option nearest in meaning to the word or phrase in italics.
In each of questions 51 to 65, choose the option opposite in meaning to the word or phrase in italics.
In each of questions 66 to 85, choose the option that best completes the gap(s).
In each of questions 86 to 88, choose the option that has the same vowel sound as the one represented by the letters underlined.
In each of questions 89 to 91, choose the option that has the same consonant sound as the one represented by the letter(s) underlined.
In each of questions 92 to 94, choose the option that rhymes with the given word.
In each of questions 95 to 97, choose the most appropriate stress pattern from the options.
In each of questions 98 to 100, the word in capital letters has the emphatic stress. Choose the option to which the given sentence relates.

questions.question: Which Use of English Paper Type is given to you?
questions.explanation: The exam paper header explicitly states 'Paper Type: D'.

questions.question: The radio station caused excitement among scientists because

options.text: it had a range of fifteen miles
it was the first to use bacteria as a power source
it was more powerful than space communication

questions.explanation: The passage states: 'For the first time, practical amounts of electricity were being produced by a form of life', confirming it was the first use of bacteria as a power source.

questions.question: The bio cell was a breakthrough because it

options.text: used solar energy to produce electricity
eliminated the need for sugar in bacterial metabolism
harnessed natural processes in living cells to generate power

questions.explanation: The passage directly says: 'The battery was a breakthrough because it used natural processes in living cells to produce electrical energy'.

questions.question: According to the passage, bacteria produce electricity when they

options.text: feed on sugar and release electrons

questions.explanation: The passage states: 'certain bacteria, when fed sugar, released electrons as a by-product of their metabolism', and those electrons were captured to generate current.

questions.question: The phrase 'life itself could be harnessed as a power source' suggests that

options.text: all living things can generate electricity
biological processes can be used intentionally for energy production
humans will no longer need fuel
plants are better than bacteria for energy

questions.explanation: The word 'harnessed' means deliberately utilized or controlled — the passage shows scientists engineered bacterial metabolism for power, confirming intentional use of biological processes.

questions.question: According to the passage, what a man thinks

options.text: is not important if his actions are good

questions.explanation: The opening sentence states: 'What a man thinks determines what he becomes', making this the directly supported answer.

questions.question: The writer compares a polluted mind to
questions.explanation: The passage uses the simile: 'Just as dirty water cannot produce clean ice, so an impure mind cannot produce wholesome conduct', explicitly comparing polluted mind to dirty water.

questions.question: Mental purification, according to the passage, begins with
questions.explanation: The passage states: 'Purification begins with awareness', making this the directly quoted answer.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT mentioned as influencing the mind?
questions.explanation: The passage lists: 'The company one keeps, the books one reads, the programmes one watches'. 'The food one eats' is not mentioned.

questions.question: The overall purpose of the passage is to

options.text: warn against the danger of evil deeds
emphasize the importance of guarding one’s thoughts
describe the function of the brain

questions.explanation: The passage repeatedly stresses guarding the mind, rejecting harmful thoughts, and mental purification, making this the central theme.

questions.question: According to the writer, people lead and motivate others because they want to
questions.explanation: The passage links leadership to personal fulfillment: 'true prosperity is in fulfilment through hard work'. 'Project individual contribution' best captures this self-actualizing motive.

questions.question: According to the passage, balance must be enthroned because it is

options.text: a serious way of ensuring success.

questions.explanation: The passage states balance discourages 'vain pursuits' and helps people accept that 'the top is not a place that all must ascend', implying it ensures realistic, sustainable success.

questions.question: The word indinations, as in the passage means
questions.explanation: The word is a likely typo for 'inclinations', which means natural tendencies or dispositions — matching context of assumptions guiding behaviour.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true according to the passage?

options.text: greatness in life emerges when square pegs are put in round holes
people do certain things in life because they know the repercussion
people agree on all issues and behave the same way for the same reason
understanding life at different levels gives no account of visible acquisition.

questions.explanation: The passage states: 'We eat because we all understand the consequences of not eating', showing actions are taken with awareness of consequences — directly supporting B.

questions.question: From the passage, it can be inferred that

options.text: People insincerely discuss facts that govern their behaviour
all managerial decisions are based on assumptions.
people make conscious effort to acquire hidden knowledge
all things in life exist on some belies.

questions.explanation: The passage states: 'We make management decisions based on the assumptions we hold...', confirming that managerial decisions are assumption-based.

questions.question: We live in an era of amazing ......16...... change
questions.explanation: The phrase 'spawned by advancing technology and industrialization' describes rapid, accelerating change — 'fast-paced' is the standard collocation.

questions.question: However, man's......17...... promoting and defending change
questions.explanation: 'Attitude to' is the grammatically correct collocation in standard British English (used by JAMB), meaning one's perspective or stance toward something.

questions.question: establish ......18...... that stimulate advancement
questions.explanation: 'Trade-zone' (or trade zone) refers to designated economic areas designed to stimulate development and commerce, fitting the context of advancement.

questions.question: with threatening ......19......
questions.explanation: 'Repercussions' means serious and unintended negative consequences — the standard term used with 'threatening' in climate discourse.

questions.question: climate change is now......20...... globe issue.
questions.explanation: 'Foremost' means most important or prominent. Given the context of 'widespread concern' and 'major test', climate change is presented as the leading global issue.

questions.question: It is a major test of Africa's......21......!
questions.explanation: A 'test' implies the need for creative problem-solving. 'Ingenuity' (cleverness and inventiveness) is the quality most logically being tested.

questions.question: disturbance in human......22...... and ecosystems
questions.explanation: 'Human life and ecosystems' is the standard phrasing in IPCC reports, referring to impacts on health, livelihoods, and survival.

questions.question: The rising global ......23...... for energy
questions.explanation: 'Rising global demand for energy' is a fixed, standard phrase in economics and environmental science.

questions.question: greenhouse ......24...... it spews out
questions.explanation: 'Greenhouse emissions' is the accepted short form of 'greenhouse gas emissions' in climate policy and science.

questions.question: a strategy that cannot, thus far, be termed ......25......
questions.explanation: If a strategy 'cannot be termed credible', it means it lacks believability or trustworthiness — fitting the critical tone toward global responsibility for Africa’s problems.

questions.question: If he were here, it could be more fun

options.text: He was expected but did not show up to make the occasion lively.
There was no fun because he was not present.
He did not show up and so the occasion lacked much fun.
He was being expected to supply more fun.

questions.explanation: The second conditional ('If he were...') implies an unreal present/future: he is absent but was expected. Option A captures both expectation and absence, explaining the reduced (but not absent) fun.

questions.question: The secretary said that the postponement of the meeting was due to unforeseen circumstances.

options.text: The date of the meeting was shifted as a result of unexpected reasons.
The meeting's date was put off for strange reasons.
The meeting was called off as a result of obstacles hitherto unknown.
The meeting broke off as a result of unusual difficulties.

questions.explanation: 'Postponement' means delay (not cancellation), and 'unforeseen circumstances' means unexpected events — 'shifted as a result of unexpected reasons' is a precise paraphrase.

questions.question: The hunter has a bird's-eye view of the animals.

options.text: He views the animal from a high position.
He views the birds on the tree with one eye.
He watches animals and birds closely.

questions.explanation: The idiom 'bird’s-eye view' means a view from a high vantage point, as if seen by a bird in flight.

questions.question: Even though Susan was the last in the examination, her result wasn't too different from what had been expected.

options.text: She did not expect to be last.
Her result was better than expected.

questions.explanation: 'Wasn’t too different from expected' means it matched expectations — therefore, it was not surprising.

questions.question: Mrs. Adasu does all her work with more haste, less speed.

options.text: She accepts whatever she does with more haste and speed.
She approaches whatever she does hurriedly.
She addresses everything she does very quickly to avoid mistakes.
She does everything carefully to avoid mistakes.

questions.explanation: The proverb 'more haste, less speed' means rushing causes inefficiency — it describes hurried, careless action, not careful work.

questions.question: She stopped her education as her uncle left her in the lurch.

options.text: Her uncle refused to help her

questions.explanation: The idiom 'left in the lurch' means abandoned in a difficult situation, especially by withdrawing expected support — i.e., refused to help.

questions.question: The plan to upgrade the dispensary to a general hospital did not materialize.

options.text: The plan did not meet the required specifications.
The arrangement did not work out as wished.
It was difficult to obtained the materials.
The materials purchased ware not the right ones.

questions.explanation: 'Did not materialize' means failed to happen or come to fruition — a neutral description captured by 'did not work out as wished'.

questions.question: Okon's company took a hit last year.

options.text: His company made a huge success last year.
His company was badly damaged last year.
His company was established last year.

questions.explanation: The idiom 'took a hit' means suffered a setback, loss, or damage — commonly used for financial or reputational harm.

questions.question: My eldest son, who is in Lagos is studying English.

options.text: Only my son is in Lagos studying English.
My only son is in Lagos studying English.
One of my son is in Lagos studying English
My sons are in Lagos but only one is studying English.

questions.explanation: The phrase 'eldest son' implies there are multiple sons. The relative clause 'who is in Lagos' identifies which son — suggesting others exist but are not in Lagos or not studying English.

questions.question: If I went to the village, I would visit the king.

options.text: If I go to the village I will visit the king.
I did not go to the village and I did not visit the king
All the times I went to village I also visited the King
I will visit the king when I go to the village

questions.explanation: The second conditional with past tense ('If I went...') refers to an unreal past situation — meaning the speaker did not go and therefore did not visit.

questions.question: Since its inception in 1983, the newspaper has attracted thousands of readers.
questions.explanation: 'Inception' means the beginning or start of something. 'Commencement' is the closest synonym among the options.

questions.question: Mrs. Asio wanted her sister to stop being so detached
questions.explanation: 'Detached' means emotionally disconnected or uninvolved. 'Indifferent' — showing no interest or concern — is the nearest synonym.

questions.question: Lantana dwelt in a ruined cottage on the hillside.
questions.explanation: 'Dwelt' is the past tense of 'dwell', meaning to live or reside in a place.

questions.question: The mistake brought the show to an ignominious end
questions.explanation: 'Ignominious' means humiliating, shameful, or disgraceful — directly matching option C.

questions.question: He compliments me on my way of doing things.
questions.explanation: 'Compliment' means an expression of praise or admiration — making 'praises' the correct synonym.

questions.question: The girl is angry with her friend who had ensnared her into this relationship.
questions.explanation: 'Ensnared' means trapped or deceived, often by subtle means — 'tricked' is the closest synonym.

questions.question: Their new house was roofed with corrugated sheets.
questions.explanation: In Nigerian usage, 'corrugated sheets' refers to corrugated iron (galvanized steel) roofing — making 'iron' the correct material reference.

questions.question: The stockbroker said it was an astute move to sell the shares then.
questions.explanation: 'Astute' means shrewd and clever, especially in practical matters — implying the move was advantageous. 'Helpful' is the nearest available synonym.

questions.question: The principal described Oche as the most tactful person he had ever worked with.
questions.explanation: 'Tactful' means sensitive, diplomatic, and discreet in dealing with others — 'discreet' (careful and prudent) is the closest match.

questions.question: The old woman is suffering from dementia.
questions.explanation: In everyday (non-clinical) usage, 'dementia' and 'senility' are often used interchangeably to describe age-related mental decline.

questions.question: Some drugs have deleterious effect on a child's development.
questions.explanation: 'Deleterious' means harmful or damaging — making 'harmful' the direct synonym.

questions.question: Fila has always described as belligerent.
questions.explanation: 'Belligerent' means hostile, aggressive, and eager to fight — synonymous with 'combative'.

questions.question: Laraba saw a forlorn little figure sitting outside the class.
questions.explanation: 'Forlorn' means pitifully sad, abandoned, and lonely — matching 'lonely and unhappy'.

questions.question: The circular supersedes all previous correspondence on the matter.
questions.explanation: 'Supersedes' means replaces or takes the place of — 'displaces' is the closest synonym among the options.

questions.question: Her problem was exacerbated by the loss of her father.
questions.explanation: 'Exacerbated' means made worse or more severe — synonymous with 'aggravated'.

questions.question: The warring communities were coerced into negotiation a settlement
questions.explanation: The instruction asks for the opposite of 'coerced' (forced). 'Persuaded' implies voluntary agreement through reasoning, making it the correct antonym.

questions.question: His father served as a mercenary in the army
questions.explanation: A 'mercenary' is a hired soldier not part of a national army. The opposite is a 'regular' soldier — one in permanent, official service.

questions.question: Jummah is cruel to her husband
questions.explanation: The opposite of 'cruel' (causing pain or suffering) is 'kind' (showing care and compassion).

questions.question: The teacher who beat the student was treated with mercy
questions.explanation: The instruction asks for the opposite of 'mercy' (compassion shown to someone one has power over). 'Vengeance' (punishment inflicted in retaliation) is the correct antonym.

questions.question: His wife hated his garrulous attitude.
questions.explanation: 'Garrulous' means excessively talkative. The opposite is 'reticent' — reserved, silent, and unwilling to speak.

questions.question: Agoshito is a callow youth; said the teacher
questions.explanation: 'Callow' means inexperienced and immature. The opposite is 'experienced'.

questions.question: What you are asking me to do is a herculean task
questions.explanation: 'Herculean' means requiring extraordinary strength or effort — extremely difficult. The opposite is 'easy'.

questions.question: Nkechi was a novice when she was first employed
questions.explanation: 'Novice' means beginner or newcomer. The opposite is 'professional' — someone with advanced skill and experience in a field.

questions.question: 'I do not trust him 'he said, in a rare moment of candour
questions.explanation: The instruction asks for the opposite of 'candour' (honesty and openness in expression). 'Dishonesty' is the correct antonym.

questions.question: Mrs Akunilo looks anaemic today
questions.explanation: 'Anaemic' refers to a condition causing paleness and fatigue due to low red blood cells. The opposite state is being 'healthy'.

questions.question: It is inconceivable that the sun shone in the night
questions.explanation: The instruction asks for the opposite of 'inconceivable' (impossible to imagine or believe). 'Credible' (able to be believed) is the correct antonym.

questions.question: She only gives a superficial impression of warmth and friendliness
questions.explanation: 'Superficial' means shallow, not profound. The opposite is 'deep' — implying sincerity and substance.

questions.question: As a prudent businessman, Adayi does not leave anything to chance
questions.explanation: 'Prudent' means acting with care and thought for the future. The opposite is 'careless' — showing lack of attention or concern.

questions.question: His antipathy affected the growth of his business
questions.explanation: 'Antipathy' means strong dislike or aversion. The opposite is 'receptiveness' — willingness to consider new ideas or accept others.

questions.question: Okonkwo's lethal right foot did the magic in the football match
questions.explanation: 'Lethal' in sports context means devastatingly effective (e.g., a powerful shot). The opposite is 'harmless' — having no effect or impact.

questions.question: When his car tyre .... on the way, he did not know what to do
questions.explanation: The simple past tense 'burst' is correct for a completed past action. 'Burst' is irregular (burst–burst–burst), and the context requires simple past, not perfect.

questions.question: Lami's father .... As a gardener when he was young, but now he is a driver
questions.explanation: 'Used to + base verb' is the correct structure for describing past habits or states that are no longer true.

questions.question: ...... He switches on the light, the shadow disappears
questions.explanation: 'Whenever' introduces a general truth or habitual action: each time he switches on the light, the shadow disappears.

questions.question: it is important that you clear the refuse in front of your house every .....
questions.explanation: 'Fortnight' is the correct spelling of the word meaning a period of two weeks.

questions.question: The policemen became suspicious as the hoodlums..... in their office
questions.explanation: The phrasal verb 'ferret about' (or 'ferret around') means to search thoroughly and intrusively — the correct collocation here.

questions.question: Suara needn't come with us...?
questions.explanation: When 'need' is used as a modal verb (without 'to'), the tag question is 'need + subject?'. So 'needn’t' → 'need she?'

questions.question: Unoka.... the whole house find his missing wristwatch
questions.explanation: 'Scoured' means searched thoroughly — the correct verb for a diligent search through a house.

questions.question: Ife asked me....

options.text: what is it by my time

questions.explanation: In reported speech, present simple ('What time is it?') changes to past simple ('what time it was').

questions.question: There are many ways to kill a rat, so we should be .... In our approach to the task ahead of us
questions.explanation: 'Eclectic' means deriving ideas, style, or taste from a broad and diverse range of sources — fitting the context of using multiple methods.

questions.question: Audu took these action purely.... His own career
questions.explanation: 'In furtherance of' is the correct prepositional phrase meaning 'for the purpose of advancing or promoting'.

questions.question: Here is Mr. Odumusu who teaches English ... in our school
questions.explanation: 'Pronunciation' is the correct spelling of the word referring to the way a word is spoken.

questions.question: Instead of... she lied
questions.explanation: 'Instead of' must be followed by a noun or gerund. 'Telling the truth' contrasts logically with 'she lied', forming a grammatically and semantically correct sentence.

questions.question: Of the three girls, Uka is the....
questions.explanation: With 'of the three', the superlative form is required. 'Naughtiest' means most badly behaved — the correct superlative of 'naughty'.

questions.question: I wonder how he will ... being absent from school for a long time
questions.explanation: The phrasal verb 'make up for' means to compensate for something lost or missed — here, making up for lost time due to absence.

questions.question: Please sit on the...
questions.explanation: 'Chair' is the correct word for a piece of furniture to sit on. The other options are misspellings of 'career'.

questions.question: I want to ... his chance to acquaint you with the latest development
questions.explanation: 'Seize the chance' is the correct idiom meaning to take an opportunity quickly and eagerly. 'Seize' is the correct spelling.

questions.question: Getting a well-paid job nowadays is on..... task
questions.explanation: 'Uphill task' is an idiom meaning a difficult or challenging task — fitting the context of job scarcity.

questions.question: The secretary has no right to ... my affairs
questions.explanation: 'Meddle in' is the correct phrasal verb meaning to interfere in something that does not concern one.

questions.question: Bola studiously avoided... the question
questions.explanation: 'Avoided answering' is a natural collocation meaning refused to respond — directly contrasted with 'studiously avoided'.

questions.question: The school authority dismissed him for .... But I won't tell you about it yet
questions.explanation: 'A certain reason' means a specific (but unspecified) reason — matching the speaker’s refusal to disclose it yet.

questions.question: bubble
questions.explanation: The vowel sound in 'bubble' is /ʌ/ (short 'u'), as in 'bull'.

questions.question: Weight
questions.explanation: 'Weight' and 'while' both have the diphthong /aɪ/ sound in standard Nigerian/British pronunciation.

questions.question: Leach
questions.explanation: In Nigerian English pronunciation, 'leach' (/liːtʃ/) and 'cheer' (/tʃiː/) share the long /iː/ vowel sound.

questions.question: mention
questions.explanation: 'Mention' and 'machine' both contain the /ʃ/ (sh) consonant sound — 'mention' ends with /ʃ/, 'machine' has /ʃ/ in the middle.

questions.question: prestige
questions.explanation: 'Prestige' and 'leisure' both end with the /ʒ/ sound (like 's' in 'measure').

questions.question: knot
questions.explanation: 'Knot' and 'cot' are homophones in many accents (silent 'k'), both pronounced /nɒt/ and /kɒt/ — sharing the same vowel and final consonant sound.

questions.question: Fuel
questions.explanation: 'Fuel' and 'cruel' rhyme in standard pronunciation: both end in /uːl/.

questions.question: match
questions.explanation: 'Match' and 'batch' are perfect rhymes: both end in /ætʃ/.

questions.question: Sheer
questions.explanation: 'Sheer' (/ʃɪə/) and 'ear' (/ɪə/) share the same vowel sound /ɪə/, making them a valid rhyme in poetry and song.

questions.question: Termination
questions.explanation: The primary stress in 'termination' falls on the fourth syllable: ter-mi-na-**TION** (/ˌtɜː.mɪˈneɪ.ʃən/).

questions.question: meditative
questions.explanation: The primary stress in 'meditative' is on the second syllable: **med-IT-a-tive** (/ˈmed.ɪ.tə.tɪv/).

questions.question: Suggestible
questions.explanation: The primary stress in 'suggestible' is on the second syllable: sug-**GEST-**i-ble (/səˈdʒes.tə.bəl/), marked as 'suggeSTIble'.

questions.question: Uche LOVES Toyota cars

options.text: What brand of car does Uche love?

questions.explanation: Emphatic stress on 'LOVES' highlights the verb — the question testing who performs the action of loving is 'Who loves Toyota cars?'

questions.question: The POLICE arrested the suspect

options.text: Did the police placate the suspect?
Did the police arrest the suspect?

questions.explanation: Emphatic stress on 'POLICE' highlights the subject — the question testing who did the action is 'Who arrested the suspect?'

questions.question: Maiduguri is the CAPITAL of Borno state

options.text: Is Maiduguri the capital of plateau state?
Which state is Maiduguri the capital of?
Is Maiduguri a town in Borno state?
What is the capital of Borno state?

questions.explanation: Emphatic stress on 'CAPITAL' highlights the noun role of Maiduguri — the question testing what Maiduguri is (i.e., its function) is 'What is the capital of Borno state?'
